figure.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a number representing an amount, especially an official number
figure.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: It’s about 30,000 in round figures (=to the nearest 10,20,100 etc).
figure.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a number from 0 to 9, written as a character rather than a word
figure.translation[0].definitions[1].not: a four/five/six figure number (=a number in the thousands, ten thousands, hundred thousands etc)
figure.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: executives with salaries in six figures (=more than £99,999)
figure.translation[0].definitions[3].def: someone who is important or famous in some way
figure.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: the outstanding political figure of his time
Several leading figures resigned from the party.
figure.translation[0].definitions[4].def: someone with a particular type of appearance or character, especially when they are far away or difficult to see
figure.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: a tall figure in a hat
Through the window I could see the commanding figure of Mrs Bradshaw.
figure.translation[0].definitions[5].def: the shape of a woman’s body
figure.translation[0].definitions[5].not: keep/lose your figure (=stay thin or become fat)
figure.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: Most women have to watch their figure (=be careful not to get fat).
figure.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: A hexagon is a six-sided figure.
figure.translation[0].definitions[7].def: a person in a painting or a model of a person
figure.translation[0].definitions[8].def: a numbered drawing or a diagram in a book
figure.translation[0].definitions[9].def: a pattern or movement in figure skating
figure.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: We exceeded our target sales figures.
There have been changes in the way the unemployment figures are calculated.
Trade figures showed a slump last month.
Government figures suggest a moderate recovery in consumer spending.
According to official figures, two million houses in England are inadequately heated.
The latest figures show that crimes are down by 0.2 percent.
The government was unable to give the exact figure for the number of foreign workers in the country.
He gave us an approximate figure for the cost of the repairs.
Can you give me a ballpark figure of the likely price?
The death toll in the region has reached five figures.
I must have made a mistake when I added up the figures.
The company will release the sales figures later this week.
Women heads of department are in single figures.
Only two of the group had scores in double figures.
In round figures, about 20 million people emigrated from Europe during that period.
According to official figures, exam results have improved again this year.
Choose a four figure number that you can easily remember.
figure.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to be an important part of a process, event, or situation, or to be included in something
figure.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Reform now figures high on the agenda.
Social issues figured prominently in the talks.
My wishes didn’t figure among his considerations.
figure.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to form a particular opinion after thinking about a situation
figure.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: It was worth the trouble, I figured.
From the way he behaved, I figured that he was drunk.
figure.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a number representing an amount, especially an officially published number
figure.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: I need this week’s sales figures.
These are the worst unemployment figures in three years.
Poor trade figures rattled the market.
February figures showed growth in lending had slowed to 5.5%.
figure.translation[2].definitions[1].def: a number written as a sign rather than a word
figure.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: In management reports, it is often worth adding up the columns of figures that are presented.
figure.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: Their economy is a mess with inflation well into double figures.
figure.translation[2].definitions[3].def: a number in the hundred thousands, millions etc, often used to talk about someone’s income
figure.translation[2].definitions[3].exa: What’s the point of a six-figure salary with no time to enjoy it?
figure.translation[2].definitions[4].exa: The event raised $200,000 for charity, and this is not the final figure.  (=the amount that will be obtained in the end)
figure.translation[2].definitions[5].def: to say exactly how much something costs, is worth etc
figure.translation[2].definitions[5].exa: Police are waiting to hear from the accountants before they can put an exact figure on the amount missing.
figure.translation[2].definitions[6].def: a numbered drawing or DIAGRAM in a book
figure.translation[2].definitions[6].exa: Figure 3.1 shows the important position of planning in the decision-making process.
figure.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: Did you figure your expenses for last month yet?
figure.translation[3].definitions[1].def: to be involved in an important part of an activity, process, or situation
figure.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: A number of top British companies all figure in his career background.
